title: 113_hr3714
content: The Act titled "Servicemembers and Veterans Prescription Drug Safety Act of 2013" establishes a Prescription Drug Take-Back Program for members of the Armed Forces and their dependents. The Act defines terms such as covered beneficiary, covered controlled substance, dependent, and eligible person, including members of the Armed Forces and individuals receiving retired pay under title 10. The Act defines terms related to individuals eligible for a program established under title 10, United States Code, including covered beneficiaries, dependents of Armed Forces members, and individuals lawfully entitled to dispose of property of those in possession of controlled substances. The program is jointly carried out by the Secretary of Defense and the Attorney General. The Secretary of Defense and the Attorney General shall jointly carry out a program under the Controlled Substances Act, allowing eligible individuals to deliver controlled substances for disposal at specified facilities. The program includes specifying the facilities and persons authorized to receive the controlled substances. The Secretary and the Attorney General will develop guidelines to prevent abuse of controlled substances delivered under the program. Regulations for the program must be prescribed within one year of the Act's enactment, with full implementation to follow within the same timeframe. SEC. 3. PRESCRIPTION DRUG TAKE-BACK PROGRAM FOR VETERANS AND THEIR DEPENDENTS. The section defines "covered controlled substance" as a controlled substance listed in specific schedules and "eligible person" as a veteran, their spouse, dependent, or someone receiving medical services from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The Department of Veterans Affairs, along with the Attorney General, must jointly carry out a program in accordance with the Controlled Substances Act. The program is established under subsection (b)(1) and the term "veteran" is defined as per section 101 of title 38, United States Code. The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Attorney General must jointly implement a program under the Controlled Substances Act, allowing eligible individuals to dispose of controlled substances at specified facilities. The Secretary and the Attorney General will determine the facilities and persons where these substances can be delivered, with a focus on preventing abuse. The Secretary and the Attorney General will develop guidelines to prevent diversion of controlled substances under the program. Regulations must be prescribed within a year of the Act's enactment, and the program must be fully implemented within a year of the regulations being prescribed.
